fields.course_name: Bachelor of Science (Agribusiness Management, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
The general objective of the Bachelor of Science in Agribusiness Management degree program is to produce a specialist graduate with strong foundations in agribusiness knowledge and management to effectively serve both the private and public sectors of the economy. The curriculum has been developed in response to the felt needs of the students, agriculture-based enterprises, and agro-based industries in Kenya. 

The specific objectives are to produce:

Graduates who will be leaders in agribusiness including managers, consultants, business solution providers, and entrepreneurs.
Scholars in agribusiness management seeking to contribute new knowledge in agribusiness and with the requisite capacity to be deployed in policy formulation and as champions of change.
To build the students’ knowledge base to increase allocative efficiency in resource use, and
To build the students outlook and attitudes through the development of skills and capacity for work and
To provide students with training and know-how on problem identification, solution, and decision-making. This program equips students with comprehensive skills in agricultural business practices, blending theoretical knowledge with practical applications in the field of agribusiness.
It aims to develop competent professionals adept at addressing the challenges and opportunities in the agriculture sector, particularly in the areas of management, technology, and sustainability.
Students will learn to analyze market trends, understand agricultural economics, and apply this knowledge to make effective business decisions in the agricultural sector.
The course also emphasizes the importance of sustainable farming practices and responsible management of agri-resources to ensure long-term profitability and environmental health.
Upon graduation, students will be prepared to tackle complex issues in agribusiness, including supply chain management, agricultural marketing, and farm business management, contributing significantly to the agricultural industry.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
In the first and second years, the programme provides students with a foundation of general agriculture, mathematics, economics, management, entrepreneurship, and the legal and policy framework relating to Agribusiness. 
In subsequent years students delve deeper into specific agri-enterprise and management related subjects. In the fourth (final) year, individual (or groups of) students develop research proposals and implement projects on topics of their choice as a requirement for successful completion of the course. 
Besides nurturing innovation and creativity in this way, the programme also allows students to combine theory and practice. Furthermore, students will undertake field or industrial attachment after completing the fourth year to gain practical experience and linkage into the job market.  The Bachelor of Science in Agribusiness Management degree program combines knowledge of business management and agricultural systems with an understanding of how the market economy works and the appropriate role of government regulation. BSc in Agribusiness Management program combines, economics and business studies disciplines to produce graduates in Agribusiness Management who will contribute to the economic development process by applying their skills in agriculture-based enterprises and agro-based industries in Kenya and the world over. Recent development concerns and trends incorporated in this program include globalization, industrialization, agricultural products value chain development, private sector development and participation in agribusiness development and management, sustainable development, and mainstreaming environmental and gender issues in the program content.

Liberalization of trade and the new millennium revolution in communication and information technology has opened up novel opportunities in agricultural trade and related business collectively called agribusiness. Consequently, there is a growing demand for training of skilled human resources to be deployed as leaders and professional practitioners in agribusiness management.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Science (Agriculture Education and Extension, With IT)
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The BSc AGED (with IT) programme will incorporate adequate courses in agricultural extension, agronomy, soil science, animal science, and agricultural economics; while at the same time covering necessary courses required for a teacher of biology and agriculture. 
This is intended to produce graduates who can serve either in the education sector or in the agricultural extension sector. 
Such multi-faceted programmes seem relevant in underdeveloped countries, Kenya included, which still struggle with high rates of unemployed graduates. 
Furthermore, the programme will provide opportunities for students to gather experience in practical rural agricultural work. They will be exposed to the actual farming environment to strengthen practical agricultural training.  
 Agricultural education encompasses the study of applied sciences (e.g. biology, chemistry, physics), agriculture, natural resources, land management, and business management principles in readiness for employment in the agricultural sector.

This Bachelor of Science in Agricultural Education and Extension degree program focuses on the needs of individuals and groups and in developing individually satisfying and socially responsible knowledge, skills, and occupational values. Such a focus recognizes the value of experiences as the context in which knowledge and skills are learned.

Agricultural education goes beyond knowledge and skills development in that students are able to develop an understanding of:

the significance of agriculture in society, through the application of scientific and business principles and problem-solving strategies; and
the interdependency and relationships between the agricultural industry and other significant businesses are interwoven with the entire economic and social structure of the community, state, nation, and world.
The BSc in Agricultural Education and Extension program prepares graduates for education and leadership positions in agriculture including teaching in schools and colleges. Graduates from this program have the relevant leadership skills necessary to transform agricultural education and extension in Kenya and globally. 

The need for agricultural education and none vocational; agricultural for farming and for non-farm occupations requiring knowledge and skill in agriculture is increasing and becoming more apparent. When farming was the occupation of the majority population, much basic agricultural knowledge was commonplace or easily obtained. The agricultural knowledge and abilities necessary for the practical affairs of the living, for effective citizenship, and for a vocational interest are no longer commonplace or easily obtained.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Science (Agronomy, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
The Bachelor of Science in Agronomy program with a focus on IT offers a comprehensive curriculum designed to equip students with a deep understanding of agricultural practices in Kenya, coupled with modern technological skills. Starting with a foundational knowledge of plant structures and functions, the program delves into essential topics such as soil science, basic chemistry, and the principles of food security. A unique aspect of this program is its integration of IT with agricultural studies, including subjects like data manipulation and analysis using spreadsheets, and the use of geographical information systems in land management.

Additionally, students explore vital areas such as soil physics, plant nutrition, and genetics, ensuring a well-rounded grasp of agronomic principles. The program also emphasizes the importance of sustainable farming practices and soil fertility management, preparing students to address contemporary challenges in agriculture. Advanced topics in the curriculum include remote sensing and GIS in land use management, tropical soils, and agricultural extension, which provide insights into the global context of agronomy.

Furthermore, the program includes a practical component in the form of an industrial attachment, allowing students to gain hands-on experience in the field. The final year focuses on research, with students undertaking a project that combines their agronomic knowledge with IT skills. This approach ensures that graduates are not only proficient in agronomic practices but also adept at utilizing technology to innovate and solve real-world agricultural problems.

To cultivate a comprehensive understanding of agronomic principles and practices, emphasizing sustainable agriculture and innovative technologies.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The degree programme provides students with fundamental theories, concepts, and hands-on practicals to enable the students to appreciate the properties of soil that are subject to manipulation in soil management for the purposes of plant crop production in a sustainable manner. Both laboratory- and field-based practicals are emphasized. The programme focuses on soil physical, chemical, and biological characteristics, soil genesis, soil survey and classification, and soil management with particular reference to plant performance. Agronomy Unit deals with teaching, research and outreach in field crops management, crop nutrient and water management, cropping systems, agro-forestry, conservation agriculture and physiology and management of abiotic stresses.Some of the research areas include plant and nutrient management in dry beans, integrated snap bean crop management, conservation agriculture in legumes and maize, micronutrient density management in vegetables, drought stress mechanisms and management in dry bean and millet, cassava agronomy, and nitrogen fixation in legumes.
 Students will explore modern agricultural technologies and practices, learning to integrate these with traditional agronomy techniques for efficient crop production.
The program includes a comprehensive study of crop protection methods, emphasizing environmentally sustainable approaches to pest and disease management.
Students are trained in the principles of seed science and technology, covering aspects like seed production, processing, storage, and quality control.
The curriculum also delves into the socio-economic aspects of agronomy, preparing students to understand and address the challenges faced by farmers and agricultural communities.
Hands-on experiences through internships and field projects are a key component, allowing students to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world agricultural scenarios.
Hands-on experiences through internships and field projects are a key component, allowing students to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world agricultural scenarios.
Bachelor of Science in Agronomy with IT integrates principles of agriculture, science, and technology to provide students with both practical and theoretical knowledge in crop production, soil management, and sustainable farming practices. The course is designed to address modern agricultural challenges through innovative approaches and IT integration. Students gain insights into the latest agronomic practices, learning how to utilize technology for efficient farm management, precision agriculture, and data analysis for decision-making. The program also covers aspects of plant genetics, pest control, and environmental conservation, equipping graduates with the skills to contribute significantly to the agriculture sector and food security initiatives. Emphasis is placed on research and hands-on experience through fieldwork and internships, preparing students for diverse careers in agronomy, agricultural research, consultancy, and agribusiness.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Science (Animal Science, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
The Bachelor of Science degree in Animal Science, integrated with IT, is meticulously designed to impart comprehensive knowledge and practical skills in the diverse aspects of animal physiology, nutrition, breeding, health, and management. This four-year university program is dedicated to enhancing the productivity and welfare of a wide range of animals, including livestock, pets, zoo animals, and wildlife. It offers students a unique opportunity to build hands-on skills through internship opportunities in various relevant industries.

Students will gain exposure to a variety of species, ranging from livestock and horses to companion and laboratory animals, fostering a well-rounded understanding of animal care and management. The program is hosted at the Roseworthy campus, known for its close-knit, animal-focused community, providing an enriching learning environment. Core studies include animal physiology, wildlife management, nutrition, and on-farm management, drawing upon the university's internationally recognized expertise in animal and veterinary sciences.

Moreover, the program integrates IT skills, equipping students with the technological tools and knowledge necessary for modern animal science practices. Optional work placements in relevant industries are available, offering real-world experience and career networking opportunities. Students will also engage in research and development activities, utilizing IT to innovate solutions for contemporary challenges in animal science. The course aims to produce skilled professionals who are capable of contributing to the field of animal science both locally and globally.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The B.Sc. degree in Animal Science is broad-based, taking foundations in Basic science courses such as anatomy, animal physiology, genetics, organic chemistry and biochemistry, and Agricultural Sciences with professional skills in Animal Production.  This is necessary for the view of the fact that as the country continues to develop, specialist manpower is required in the extension service, public agricultural institutions, private sector, and non-governmental organizations. The Department of Animal Science primarily aims at producing graduates who are competent in animal science, responsive to industry needs and with ability to integrate computer technology in the science and art of livestock production. To achieve this, the departmental emphasizes quality research to generate knowledge that informs graduate training. Consequently the curricula for the various programmes are characterized by dynamic content. The graduates of the Department are trained to gain competencies in practical aspects of the four key pillars of animal production namely animal health; animal nutrition; animal breeding and animal production systems as well as entrepreneurial skills to enable them create jobs as well as fit well in the job market. Besides, the curriculum prepares the graduates for further academic development and careers in teaching, research and extension. Animal Science is an applied science discipline dealing with the conservation, improvement, production, processing, distribution, and utilization of animal products.

This Bachelor of Science degree in Animal Science is designed to provide students with fundamental knowledge and skills in the fields of Physiology, Nutrition, Breeding, Animal Health, Ecology, and Management of various species of domestic animals. Supporting courses in Crop Production (e.g. Pastures and Fodders crops), Agricultural Economics, and Extension are also offered.

Animal production plays a major role in the economy of Kenya economy by providing food, shelter, employment, and cash income, in addition to several socio-cultural functions. As food, animal protein is essential, especially for proper physical as well as mental development. The fast population growth in the country puts a high demand for increased productivity in agriculture. With Kenya’s advance to industrialization under Vision 2030 and beyond, the need to increase agricultural production in order to avail adequate food for the population as well as providing raw materials for industrial processing has become even greater. Kenya’s agriculture is largely based on smallholder farming systems. Consequently, mixed crop-livestock systems are the most appropriate production systems for sustainable farming within the smallholder-farming sub-sector in the country. The course program will equip its graduates to face the challenges of national, regional, and global animal production.
fields.general_prerequisites:
Candidates wishing to pursue a B.Sc. degree program in Animal Science with IT must meet the minimum admission requirements of Maseno University. In addition, the candidate should have attained at least C+ in Biology/Biological Sciences or B- in Agriculture; C (plain) in Chemistry/Physical Sciences and C_ in Mathematics or Physics at KCSE.
Applicants who hold a diploma in a relevant animal science field will be given credit transfers in equivalent animal science courses taken and passed (with a minimum grade score of B) at diploma level. Only up to one-third of the total programme course units taken can be transferred.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Science (Fisheries and Aquaculture, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
Animal and fisheries sciences play a crucial role in achieving food and nutrition security by providing the necessary knowledge and technologies for the sustainable production and management of animal and fisheries resources. These disciplines focus on improving animal and fish production systems, breeding, health, and nutrition, as well as aquatic resource conservation and socio-economics in the respective value chains. By promoting sustainable management practices, developing new technologies, and enhancing productivity, animal and fisheries sciences help to ensure the availability and affordability of high-quality animal and fish products, which are essential for achieving food security and meeting the nutritional needs of communities. Students will explore advanced techniques in aquaculture and fisheries management, including the use of IT tools for resource tracking and data analysis, contributing to the efficient and ethical use of aquatic resources.
The curriculum also encompasses the study of aquatic ecosystems, emphasizing the importance of environmental sustainability in fisheries and aquaculture practices.
As part of the program, students will undertake fieldwork and laboratory exercises, gaining practical experience in fish breeding, hatchery management, and aquatic health diagnostics. The program includes in-depth studies on innovative aquaculture technologies, focusing on sustainable and eco-friendly practices to enhance fish production.
Students will learn about the latest advancements in marine biotechnology and its application in fisheries science for species conservation and genetic improvement.
There will be a focus on developing skills in policy formulation and management strategies to address the challenges facing global fisheries and aquaculture sectors.
The course also covers the impact of climate change on aquatic ecosystems and strategies for adaptation and mitigation in fisheries and aquaculture.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
Animal and fisheries sciences play a crucial role in achieving food and nutrition security by providing the necessary knowledge and technologies for the sustainable production and management of animal and fisheries resources. These disciplines focus on improving animal and fish production systems, breeding, health, and nutrition, as well as aquatic resource conservation and socio-economics in the respective value chains. By promoting sustainable management practices, developing new technologies, and enhancing productivity, animal and fisheries sciences help to ensure the availability and affordability of high-quality animal and fish products, which are essential for achieving food security and meeting the nutritional needs of communities.

The Department of Animal and Fisheries Sciences (DAnFis) is committed to supporting Kenya's food security agenda and its vision for industrialization by 2030, in alignment with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Our Animal and fisheries science programs play a critical role in supporting national government food security plans by ensuring the availability of safe and nutritious animal and fisheries products, promoting sustainable production practices, and supporting economic growth and poverty reduction. Our fisheries programs support the health of our oceans, rivers, and lakes, and in preserving the diversity of aquatic species for future generations. These are strategic pillars of exploiting the blue economy resources, which have immense socio-economic potential for humanity. Meanwhile, our animal science programs support food security by advancing knowledge and practices that can help to optimize animal health, welfare, and productivity, while minimizing environmental impacts and ensuring the safety and quality of animal-based food products.

DAnFiS recognizes the crucial role played by animal, fisheries, and aquatic resources sectors in achieving sustainable food and nutrition sufficiency, as well as national economic progress. To achieve these goals, the department prioritizes sound teaching, research, capacity building, and technology transfer initiatives aimed at educating and training young adults and communities. Currently,  we offer robust and tailor-made undergraduate and postgraduate research programs that allow students to engage in interdisciplinary research activities relevant to real-life situations in the fields of Fisheries and Aquaculture, Animal Science, Aquatic Resources Conservation and Development, and Animal Health and Production. In addition, the department offers programs, such as the Diploma in Aquaculture Production and Management and the Diploma in Animal Health and Production, to further support these objectives.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Science (Horticulture, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
The horticultural sector has acquired a bigger role in the economy of Kenya in generating self-employment and increasing income for the rural population. There is, therefore, a dire need for highly qualified manpower to provide the necessary skills to sustain and expand production for the local market, raw materials for the processing industry, and fresh exports.

The Bachelor of Science degree program in Horticulture is thus aimed at bringing about the realization of this potential. The broad objective of the program is to train high-level manpower with practical and theoretical skills in general horticulture who will, through research, extension, marketing, and self-employment, be able to improve and increase both the production of horticultural and other crops. At the end of the program the graduates should be able to:

Perceive the importance of horticulture in the national economy with particular reference to the role of vegetables, fruits, and flowers in meeting the family needs for food, clothing, and shelter.
Make use of the acquired knowledge and practical skills to raise production and improve the marketing of horticultural crops and products on both small and large-scale farms.
Set up and run a thriving private horticultural enterprise on vegetables, fruits, or flowers.
Using acquired knowledge and practical skills, be able to relate and integrate the production of horticultural crops with other farm enterprises.
Carry out simple, but meaningful scientific research on various facets of horticultural and other crop enterprises.
Promote environmental conservation by encouraging and effecting practices that minimize soil erosion and pollution from pesticides.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The Bachelor of Science in Horticulture degree program is an applied science discipline dealing with the conservation, improvement, production, processing, distribution, and utilization of fruits, vegetables, flowers, and other ornamental plants. This BSc in Horticulture program trains advanced level personnel with practical and theoretical skills in general horticulture, who through research, extension, marketing, and entrepreneurship, will be able to increase production and use of horticultural and other crops.
Horticulture is a fast-growing and major subsector of the agricultural industry in Kenya. Its contribution towards both small-scale and large-scale farm incomes, employment, foreign exchange earnings, and food production security cannot be overemphasized. However, the full potential of horticulture is yet to be realized, hence the need for a highly qualified workforce to drive the industry. The major goal of the Bachelor of Science in horticulture is to prepare the graduates to meet challenges faced by the horticultural industry in realizing its full potential.
Competent graduate horticulturists from this program are capable of integrating horticultural components in farming systems; provide technical solutions compatible with the available resources; conversing with large-scale and specialized corporate horticultural production and smallholder horticulture systems, greenhouse production sustainably with local and export marketing skills.
The program covers advanced plant breeding techniques, focusing on genetic improvement for enhanced yield, quality, and resistance to pests and diseases.
Students will learn about post-harvest technology, including the latest methods in storage, preservation, and value addition to horticultural produce.
The curriculum includes comprehensive training in landscape design and management, equipping students with skills for urban and rural landscape planning.
There's a strong emphasis on sustainable horticultural practices, teaching students how to balance productivity with environmental conservation.
The course also includes modules on agribusiness management, preparing students for entrepreneurship in the horticultural sector.
Practical learning is facilitated through field trips, internships, and research projects, connecting students with industry leaders and real-world horticultural challenges.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Science (Geography and Natural Resource Management, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
Apply the acquired knowledge in ecological, sociological, technical and economic concepts to the theory and practice of natural resource conservation, utilization and management.
Communicate this knowledge and management techniques to the relevant members of the society at large.
Analyse and evaluate critical issues in natural resource policy, conservation, utilization and management.
The basic objective of the Bachelor of Science in Environment and Natural Resource Management is to equip students with relevant technical and professional knowledge that will enable them to effectively manage, conserve and utilize resources wherever they are employed. The specific objective at the end of the program is that the students will be able to;

1. Apply the acquired knowledge in ecological, sociological and economic concepts to the theory and practice of dry-land natural resources management, utilization and conservation.
2. Communicate this knowledge to the stakeholders. Develop skills for the sustainable management of water resources, focusing on innovative techniques for water conservation and watershed management.
Gain a comprehensive understanding of the role of geographic information systems (GIS) and remote sensing in natural resource management, enabling the analysis and interpretation of environmental data.
Study the effects of climate change on natural ecosystems, learning strategies to mitigate its impact and promote resilience in natural resource management.
Explore the socio-economic aspects of resource management, including community engagement and participatory approaches in resource conservation and development.
Learn about renewable energy resources and their potential in sustainable environmental management, analyzing the balance between development and conservation.
Understand the legal and policy frameworks governing natural resource management, focusing on international and national regulations and their implementation.

 The prime consideration of man as the most intelligent being on this planet is to utilize and conserve the existing natural resources for sustainable development. The process requires continued understanding by man of the biotic and the abiotic conditions and their interrelationships. There is no greater long-term need in Kenya today than the conservation and management of her vast arid and semi-arid lands ASALS., fauna and flora, the natural forests, water-catchment areas, wetlands, and the aquatic life. The pressure on natural resources for fuel and timber and on land in general, for crops and pasture, has led to forest recession, soil erosion, desertification and water-catchment degradation - all of which combine to impair the land and water resources. 
Kenya being a small "niche" on the global environmental complex system needs to produce competent natural resource conservationists / managers who will make effort to facilitate utilization and conservation of her natural resources without upsetting the environmental equilibrium. 
The approach to education and training must accordingly be re-oriented. The emphasis needs to shift from a narrow base to a broad base so as to effect integration. The main objective is to produce resource conservationists and managers who are multi-disciplinary in approach and can view the management of natural resources holistically. 
The purpose of this BSc. Natural Resource Management degree programme at Egerton University is to offer educational opportunities to students who desire a broad knowledge in the management of renewable and non-renewable natural resources. Emphasis is placed on an ecological approach relative to the conservation and management of natural resources.
Increasing opportunities for employment of graduates with background in the management of Forestry and Watershed Resources, Arid and Semi-Arid Lands Resources, Wildlife and Fisheries Resources and Non-Renewable Resources are available in public and private sections. 
The BSc. Natural Resource Management graduates from Egerton University will be deployed in areas such as resources use planning, environmental monitoring and impact studies, natural resource development, conservation information and education, and regulatory activities.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Science (Climate Change and Development, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
Develop capacity on the assessment of the impacts of climate change  on  human and natural environments.
Evaluate relevant climate change adaptation and mitigation options.
Possess necessary skills for team work in an industrial and scientific research environment.
Undertake postgraduate work in climate change science and its related fields. Acquire expertise in climate modeling and prediction, utilizing advanced tools and techniques to forecast climate trends and their implications for society and the environment.
Engage in policy analysis and advocacy, understanding the role of national and international policies in addressing climate change challenges.
Develop practical skills in sustainable environmental management, focusing on eco-friendly practices that reduce the carbon footprint and enhance environmental sustainability.
Gain insights into renewable energy technologies, exploring how they contribute to climate change mitigation and sustainable development.
Study the socio-economic impacts of climate change, including its effects on agriculture, water resources, and human settlements, and learn strategies to build climate-resilient communities.
Understand the ethical and equity considerations in climate change, particularly in relation to vulnerable populations and developing countries.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
Bachelor of Science (Climate Change and Development, With IT) offers a comprehensive understanding of the multifaceted aspects of climate change and its impact on various ecosystems. Students will explore critical topics such as hydrology, oceanography, Earth systems science, environmental studies, biodiversity conservation, paleoclimatology, renewable and non-renewable energy resources, and atmospheric science. The curriculum delves into the human dimension of global environmental change, focusing on climate dynamics, impacts on agriculture, water resources, human health, human settlements, tropical and arid environments, and energy. Emphasis is placed on understanding the social dimensions of development, remote sensing, climate classification, and vulnerability assessment. The program includes advanced studies in climate change mitigation, adaptation strategies, sustainable development, policy and regulations, quantitative methods, and global responses to climate change. Students will gain practical skills in water resource management, information technology applications in climate studies, disaster management, environmental assessment, and project management, preparing them to address the challenges of climate change in various sectors.
This program emphasizes the integration of information technology in climate science, offering students hands-on experience in using advanced software and tools for climate data analysis and interpretation."
"Students are exposed to case studies and real-world scenarios, equipping them with the skills to develop practical solutions for climate resilience and sustainable development in various sectors."
"Collaborative projects and workshops with industry professionals and environmental organizations provide students with a unique opportunity to understand the challenges and innovations in climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies."
"The course also delves into the socio-economic impacts of climate change, preparing graduates to address complex environmental issues while considering the balance between technological advancements and societal needs."

Advances in technology have made it possible for people of different cultures and countries to interact, but it is human skills in communication that will ensure that the interactions are positive and constructive. Corporations have recognized the need for better communication hence the increased use of communicative facilities.

Also rapidly expanding are career opportunities for writers and editors in technical fields, computer software. The graduates of this programme will work in the following areas; print media (editors and writers) television media (presenters, editors, producers and screenwriters), public relations officers, business managers, consultants, diplomats, teachers, lecturers, researchers and photojournalists.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Arts (Criminology, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
Criminology and Security Studies focuses on analyzing crimes and criminals in order to understand their motives and find ways to prevent future crimes. It also analyses trends and the impact of crimes on human societies. Another important aspect of Criminology is the evaluation of punishment and rehabilitation methods in order to determine their efficacy and ways to improve them.

Criminology incorporates and examines broader knowledge about crime and criminals. For example, criminologists have attempted to understand why some people are more or less likely to engage in criminal or delinquent behavior. Criminologists have also examined and attempted to explain differences in crime rates and the criminal code between societies and changes in rates and laws over time.

The programme is designed for students who wish to pursue careers in police services, forensic investigations, human rehabilitation services and security management.

Graduates of this programme will be prepared to take up managerial positions in the public sector especially in; the police service, prisons and probation departments. The private sector will find the graduates useful in security management and related roles. In general, it is expected that this programme will complement and sustain the professionalization of the police, prison and probation services in East Africa and beyond.

By the end of the course, the learner should be able to:

Take up responsibilities in the dynamic security industry.
Demonstrate leadership in the area of community policing
Use the knowledge and skills acquired to take up entrepreneurial roles in the country and internationally
Conduct research in criminology and the security field.
Identify new models of peacebuilding and conflict management as a way of managing security.
Identify emerging human security threats such as piracy, human trafficking, terrorism
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
Criminology and Security Studies is a branch of sociology (which traditionally examines human behavior, interaction, and organization) that also ties in research and concepts from other areas of study, such as philosophy, anthropology, biology, and psychology.

Criminology is the study of crime from a social perspective, including examining who commits crimes, why they commit them, their impact, and how to prevent them from committing a crime. Criminology is an analytical and applied field of study that focuses on the understanding, control, and prevention of crime and criminal behavior. It is an interdisciplinary field that draws from study areas such as sociology, anthropology, economics, psychology, psychiatry, history, political science, and philosophy. It also draws from professions such as law, medicine, and social work.

Security studies incorporate data analysis, leadership, and systematic thinking to identify and protect against a wide range of threats, including both man-made and natural causes of disasters and other shocks.

Students in Criminology and Security Studies programs look at how age, sex, education, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status affect crime levels, as well as the various methods the justice system uses to process relevant data. The end goal of criminology and security studies is to determine the root causes of criminal behavior and to develop effective and humane means for preventing it. These goals have produced several schools of thought within the discipline, each of which looks at different factors involved in deviant behavior and comes to different conclusions about how best to approach the issues.

Every threat a community or company faces from cyberattacks and terrorism to climate change and pandemics has the potential to significantly affect its members and operations. Professionals in the security sector work hard to not only lead recovery efforts after a disaster but to identify and eliminate these threats in the first place. Many criminologists consider themselves to be neutral public policy experts, gathering facts for various governmental officials responsible for drawing policy conclusions. However, some criminologists—like their counterparts in such fields as the atomic and nuclear sciences—maintain that scientists must shoulder responsibility for the moral and political consequences of their research. Thus, some criminologists have actively campaigned against capital punishment and have advocated in favor of various legal reforms. Criminologists who oppose this activist role contend that the findings of criminological research must be weighed along with political, social, religious, and moral arguments, a task best left to political bodies. Not denying the right of criminologists to express their opinions as ordinary citizens and voters, this view nonetheless maintains that a government by popular will is less dangerous than a government by experts.

It covers a wide scope of performing art specializations, including dance techniques and choreography, plays directing, drama instruction, sound engineering, music and theatre Journalism, music and theatre entrepreneurship, music therapy, music composition, and performance, aimed at equipping individuals with requisite knowledge and skills to participate in the growing creative economy both locally and globally. To train students in professional skills within the area of creative and performing arts with an aim of enabling them to actively  engage in the developmental aspects of community work.
To train students for self employment by using acquired skills in creative and performing arts.
To improve the skills of practicing actors, technicians,music educators and performers, producers, directors, theatre educators and performers, and community workers who may need professional skills and in-servicein order to work competently.
To train students to study and broaden ideas in the performing arts through research, training and teaching.
To equip students with skills in running various outreach academic and community programs e.g. Drama/Theatre in Community Development, Theatre in Education and Musical theatre therapy. Foster artistic innovation and creativity, enabling students to conceptualize and produce original theatrical works that reflect contemporary themes and societal issues.
Provide in-depth understanding of the history and theory of drama and theatre, exploring various cultural and historical contexts of performance arts.
Develop technical proficiency in stagecraft, including set design, lighting, costume, and makeup, enhancing the overall quality of theatrical productions.
Encourage collaboration and teamwork, as students will work on joint projects, learning the dynamics of effective communication and leadership in the arts.
Prepare students for diverse roles in the entertainment industry, ranging from acting and directing to technical production and arts administration.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The Bachelor of Arts (Drama and Theatre Studies, With IT) program at JKUAT is an innovative and comprehensive program that blends music, dance, and theatre to offer a holistic approach to the performing arts. It encompasses a wide range of specializations such as dance techniques and choreography, plays directing, drama instruction, sound engineering, music and theatre journalism, music and theatre entrepreneurship, music therapy, music composition, and performance. This curriculum is designed to equip students with the necessary knowledge and skills to actively participate in the growing creative economy, both locally and globally.

The program spans four years, each with two semesters, and covers a variety of courses. In the first year, students are introduced to music and theatre appreciation, the fundamentals of performing arts, theatre laboratory, dance and movement, development of music and drama, practical performance, and foundational IT skills. The second year deepens their understanding with courses in music theory, musicianship, the philosophy of dance, performing arts therapy, the role of performing arts in education and society, advanced practical performance, and IT applications.

The third year offers specializations in either music or theatre studies. The music specialization includes advanced music theory, composition, music history, analysis, and technology, with a strong emphasis on practical performance. The theatre studies specialization, on the other hand, focuses on scripting, directing, acting, dance techniques, and the technical aspects of theatre production.

In the final year, students in the music specialization explore advanced composition, orchestration, conducting, ethnomusicology, music production, and technology, along with advanced practical performance. Those specializing in theatre studies delve into advanced areas such as scenography, lighting, theatre management and marketing, oriental theatre, drama for children and youth, and editing for electronic media.

The program culminates with a comprehensive understanding of the performing arts, preparing students for a variety of roles in the entertainment industry, education, community development, and media. The integration of IT skills ensures that graduates are well-equipped to navigate the digital aspects of the modern creative industry.

Design, in the Bachelor of Arts in Design degree programme at the University of Nairobi, is an accelerating factor which plays an important role side by side with productivity and management.
The aims and objectives of the four year Bachelor of Arts in Design degree programme at the University of Nairobi are based on professional education for national development.
Design education entails making the students aware of the economic, commercial, industrial and technological factors on design activities.
Among others, professional design education includes:
Promotion of interdisciplinary integration of artistic, scientific, socio-political, environmental and technological knowledge.
Creativity in problem-solving processes in areas pertaining to human communication and needs.
Encouraging and promoting research.
The awareness of the role and need for team work with production, management, and other decision makers.
Attainment of professional standards, skills and draughtsmanship.
Taking into account national objectives of education and economic development such as visual communication and literacy, culture, self-technological needs and trends. Cultivate a deep understanding of historical and contemporary art movements, enabling students to place their work within a broader artistic and cultural context.
Develop critical thinking and analytical skills through the study of art theory, criticism, and aesthetics, fostering a nuanced appreciation of artistic forms.
Provide practical experience in various artistic mediums, from traditional painting and sculpture to digital and multimedia art, broadening students' creative horizons.
Encourage exploration of personal artistic style and voice, guiding students to create a distinctive body of work that reflects their individual perspectives.
Offer opportunities for public exhibitions and critiques, giving students valuable exposure and feedback from peers, faculty, and art professionals.
Equip students with the skills necessary for a successful career in the arts, including portfolio development, marketing, and professional networking.

Encourage community engagement and social impact through art, inspiring students to use their talents for positive change and cultural enrichment.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
Fine art is a human ability to transform an idea into a form. The form so created is skillfully articulated to satisfy aesthetic or utilitarian factions. This course contributes immensely in all areas of the society such as social, cultural, economic, political, historical, utilitarian and personal expression. This programme provides an opportunity to students to engage with a contemporary approach to traditional media; have an exploration of textile in fine art context; digital media in the form of still motion images; interdisciplinary practice that cuts across the boundaries of traditional media; contextual research in contemporary artistic practice; visual research that promotes exploration and speculation; art criticism and the development of analytical and interpretive thinking. The aim of the course is the achievement of authentic, personal approach to art making, relevant contemporary art and discourse in preparation for a chosen career in the visual art industry.

Preparation for life after university is recognized as an important part of the curriculum. The students will concentrate on their areas of specialization in the last 3 years of study. Course in the current programme are in tandem with those offered in other universities globally and are taught by qualified staff in the department of Art and Design. During the four year degree programme, the courses are designed to expose students to a range of topics within Fine Art. Students are equipped with theoretical and practical skills which enable them to pursue careers in various Fine Art fields and research. To satisfy the stakeholders' requirements the programme is reviewed after every four years. The programme is in tandem with Kenya's vision 2030 that points out on development of talents to encourage self employment and job creation. Therefore the programme is within standards of undergraduate Fine Art courses offered both in Kenya and other reputable Universities globally.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Arts (French, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
Their objectives are:


i) To equip students with the knowledge of the French language that will enable them to operate, in French, in diverse academic and professional fields.


ii) To initiate students into the professions of translation and interpretation.


iii) With special reference to the material taught under the BA programme, to train students in rigorous and critical examination of phenomena, thereby prepare them for both academic and functional research.
iv) To develop students' ability to effectively communicate in French, both orally and in writing, across various contexts and audiences.

v) To enhance cultural awareness and understanding of Francophone countries and communities, fostering global citizenship and multicultural competence.

vi) To provide a strong foundation in French literature, linguistics, and contemporary issues, enabling students to appreciate the diversity and richness of the French-speaking world.

vii) To offer practical experience and exposure through language immersion opportunities, study abroad programs, and interactions with native French speakers.

viii) To encourage the application of French language skills in technology, business, and international relations, aligning with modern professional demands.

ix) To instill a love for lifelong learning of languages, promoting personal and professional growth in an increasingly interconnected world.
x) To prepare students for advanced studies in French language and literature, paving the way for careers in education, translation, international diplomacy, and more.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The Bachelor of Arts in French with IT at JKUAT offers a comprehensive curriculum designed to provide students with a deep understanding of the French language, literature, and culture. This four-year program is divided into several key areas of study, including language for communication, linguistics, culture and civilization of the French-speaking world, literature, translation, and research methods.

Throughout the first year, students build foundational skills in French language and oral expression, including a contrastive approach to French and other languages. The second year delves into the culture and civilization of French-speaking Africa, France, and the Caribbean Francophone world, along with linguistic studies, history of the language, literary analysis, Francophone literature, and basic translation skills.

In the third year, the program expands to cover French for academic and professional purposes, examining the French language's presence in various regions including Europe, the Americas, the Arab world, Asia, and the Pacific. It also introduces students to theories of linguistics and literary analysis, covering the oral literature of the French-speaking world.

The fourth year focuses on specialized applications of French, such as business, hotel, travel, tourism, management, administration, diplomacy, and international relations. It also explores advanced topics in semantics, lexicology, phonetics, phonology, literary theories, and oral literature from various regions. The program culminates with a project paper for majoring students.

This program not only equips students with fluency in French but also integrates IT skills, making graduates versatile in various professional fields such as translation, diplomacy, academia, journalism, and the hospitality industry. The Bachelor of Arts in French with IT is aligned with market demands, preparing students not only for employment but also for entrepreneurial opportunities. Additionally, the program supports the training of high school French teachers, further contributing to the educational landscape.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Arts (History and Archaeology, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
To give the specializing student a broad background in the fields of Archaeology, Palaeoanthropology, Cultural Resource Management, Conservation and Museology in preparation for graduate work, professional research and formal employment.
        To give the non-specializing student a general education that includes the understanding of humanity and their adaptation to the environment through time, culture history, reconstruction of past life ways and an explanation of cultural process.
         To prepare the student as a capable researcher and disseminator of knowledge in the profession of the disciplines of Archaeology and Palaeoanthropology,.
         To expose the student to related disciplines that can be used to obtain the maximum information from the archaeological record.
		 To develop students' analytical skills in interpreting archaeological findings and understanding their significance in the broader context of human history.

To instill a comprehensive understanding of various archaeological techniques and methodologies, including fieldwork, excavation, and data analysis.

To encourage a multidisciplinary approach, integrating insights from geography, anthropology, and environmental science into archaeological studies.

To foster an appreciation of the ethical considerations and responsibilities involved in archaeological practice, particularly in relation to heritage preservation and cultural sensitivities.

To equip students with practical experience through field trips, internships, and collaborations with museums and research institutions.

To prepare students for careers in academia, cultural resource management, heritage conservation, and other related fields where expertise in history and archaeology is valued.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The Bachelor of Arts in History and Archaeology with IT at JKUAT is designed to produce graduates equipped with the knowledge, skills, and attitudes necessary to contribute meaningfully to socio-economic and political developments. This program provides an in-depth exploration of both African history and archaeology, focusing on various critical periods and themes that have shaped the continent and its interaction with the world.

The program covers African history from ancient times to the contemporary period, including key events and developments since 1895, such as imperialism, nationalism, and the history of urbanization in Africa. It also provides a comprehensive introduction to archaeology, offering insights into both general archaeological practices and African-specific archaeological studies.

Courses in the program delve into African history before and after colonialism, examining the continent's rich heritage and complex interactions with external powers. The curriculum also includes a unique look at the relationship between the United States of America and Africa, providing students with a broader perspective on international relations.

Furthermore, the program addresses key themes in African archaeology, allowing students to understand the historical context of archaeological finds and their significance in reconstructing Africa's past. By integrating IT skills into the curriculum, the program ensures that graduates are well-prepared for the modern workforce, capable of utilizing technology in historical and archaeological research.

This blend of history, archaeology, and IT equips students with a unique set of skills and knowledge, making them valuable contributors in various fields, including academia, cultural resource management, heritage conservation, and more. The program's comprehensive approach ensures that graduates are well-versed in understanding and interpreting Africa's past and its implications for contemporary societal development.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Arts (Interior Design, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
Interior Design transforms built environments into functional and habitable spaces. The focus of the Programme is to enhance the quality of life through the designing interior spaces and the extended environment. Skills that transform interior spaces into effective settings for various human activities are gained. Emphasis is on the development of technical skills, creative problem solving and management skills. Interior Designers are tasked with enhancing the aesthetic value of spaces based on the organization of principles and elements of design. The program mentors individuals to fit in the World of Work after the attainment of techniques and skills which enable them become professionals in design consultancy, program management, space planning, display design, drafting and furniture design.
 Design, in the Bachelor of Arts in Design degree programme at the University of Nairobi, is an accelerating factor which plays an important role side by side with productivity and management.
The aims and objectives of the four year Bachelor of Arts in Design degree programme at the University of Nairobi are based on professional education for national development.
Design education entails making the students aware of the economic, commercial, industrial and technological factors on design activities.
Among others, professional design education includes:
Promotion of interdisciplinary integration of artistic, scientific, socio-political, environmental and technological knowledge.
Creativity in problem-solving processes in areas pertaining to human communication and needs.
Encouraging and promoting research.
The awareness of the role and need for team work with production, management, and other decision makers.
Attainment of professional standards, skills and draughtsmanship.
Taking into account national objectives of education and economic development such as visual communication and literacy, culture, self-technological needs and trends.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
Despite considerable technological progress, a noticeable degree of poor housing, and interior design, health and sanitation prevails in both rural and urban areas. The programme aims at producing a cadre of trained professionals, who will advise and demonstrate approaches and techniques of altering the living environment. Moreover, there is growing demand for competent personnel in the areas of clothing, textiles and interior design with increased opportunities created by East African Federation, COMESA, and the international markets.
 The Bachelor of Arts in Interior Design with IT is a comprehensive program that seeks to address the challenges of poor housing and interior design prevalent in both rural and urban settings. This program is crafted to produce skilled professionals adept in offering innovative and practical solutions for enhancing living environments. The curriculum is designed to equip students with the knowledge and techniques necessary to improve health and sanitation through effective interior design.

The program places a strong emphasis on understanding the dynamics of modern housing and interior design, focusing on the application of technology and creative design principles to transform living spaces. Students will learn about various aspects of interior design, including space planning, material selection, color theory, lighting, and furniture design. The integration of IT skills ensures that students are proficient in using modern design software and tools, making them adaptable to the evolving demands of the design industry.

Recognizing the growing demand for qualified professionals in the fields of clothing, textiles, and interior design, the program also prepares students to meet the needs of diverse markets. With opportunities expanding due to regional integrations like the East African Federation and COMESA, as well as international markets, graduates of this program will be well-positioned to contribute significantly in various sectors. They will be capable of advising on and demonstrating contemporary design techniques that cater to both aesthetic and functional requirements of modern living spaces.

This program is thus an ideal choice for those aspiring to become influential interior designers, capable of shaping the future of living environments through innovative and sustainable design solutions.

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Arts (Kiswahili, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
The programme endeavors to produce experts capable of participating actively in the studies of Kiswahili language, linguistics, and also literature for the social, political, and economic development in Kenya, the East and Central African region, and globally.  To impart in-depth knowledge and understanding of Kiswahili language structure, its historical development, and its role in contemporary society.

To explore the rich literary heritage of the Kiswahili language, encompassing both traditional and modern works.

To develop students' skills in oral and written communication in Kiswahili, enhancing their ability to effectively convey ideas and information.

To provide students with the tools to undertake critical and analytical research in Kiswahili language and literature.

To foster an appreciation of the cultural and societal contributions of Kiswahili-speaking communities.

To prepare students for diverse careers where Kiswahili language proficiency is essential, including education, translation, media, and international relations.

To encourage the use of technology in the study and dissemination of Kiswahili language and literature.

To build a foundation for advanced studies in Kiswahili, linguistics, and related fields.

To promote Kiswahili as a tool for regional integration and international communication, reflecting its status as a major African language.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The Bachelor of Arts in Kiswahili with IT is an extensive and comprehensive program that delves deep into the Kiswahili language, its linguistics, and literature. It aims to produce experts who can contribute significantly to various sectors such as education, translation, media, and diplomacy, both in Kenya and globally.

The program's course distribution spans four years, each with two semesters, and covers a wide range of topics:

Year I Semester I focuses on foundational aspects of language and linguistics, including Introduction to Kiswahili Literature, Language Acquisition, and the Art of Writing in Kiswahili, alongside foundational IT courses.

Year I Semester II continues with advanced language studies, exploring Linguistic Theory, Language and Society, and Kiswahili Culture, complemented by computer communication systems and data manipulation skills.

Year II Semester I elevates the learning to theory and standardization of Kiswahili, communication skills, pragmatics, and theatre and drama, integrated with internet and desktop publishing techniques.

Year II Semester II delves into oral literature, Kiswahili poetry, terminography, and stylistics, along with courses in computer-based systems and relational database management.

Year III Semester I expands into phonetics, critical literary theory, oral literature, translation, contemporary literature trends, and creative writing, with a focus on technology management and multimedia systems.

Year III Semester II covers Kiswahili phonology, historical and comparative linguistics, pre-20th-century poetry, translation, and short stories, as well as electronic commerce and statistical data analysis.

Year IV Semester I features advanced studies in morphology, sociolinguistics, Kiswahili plays, research methods, discourse analysis, and Kiswahili in the diaspora, along with courses in IT social and professional issues, information assurance, and hospitality industry applications.

Year IV Semester II culminates with syntax, semantics, language planning, Kiswahili novels, research projects, lexicography, psycholinguistics, comparative literature, and an industrial/practical attachment, coupled with advanced IT topics in human-computer interaction and contemporary ICTs.

This program is strategically designed to prepare students for a broad spectrum of career opportunities where Kiswahili language proficiency is essential. It is particularly notable for its integration of information technology, making graduates well-equipped for the modern, digital world.

This is consistent with social pillar in the Vision 2030 policy document, where quality education in academic institutions constitutes a pillar of development especially in the generation of qualified and skilled personnel to serve various sectors in the country where services of language and communication experts are essential. The Bachelor of Arts (Language and Communication) programme exposes students to theoretical thinking in both Linguistics and Communication. Trained Graduates of this programmme can exercise their skills in the fields of academic, Non Government Institutions and even in International Organisations.
 To enable students to understand the intricate relationship between language, culture, and communication, fostering a comprehensive understanding of linguistic diversity and its implications.

To provide students with a solid foundation in language theory, communication strategies, and linguistic analysis, equipping them with the skills needed to navigate and analyze complex communicative situations.

To enhance students' abilities in effective communication across various platforms, including digital media, preparing them for the evolving landscape of global communication.

To cultivate critical thinking and analytical skills, enabling students to engage with language and communication issues in a thoughtful and informed manner.

To prepare students for careers that require strong communication skills, such as journalism, public relations, marketing, and education, where they can apply their knowledge creatively and innovatively.

fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The Bachelor of Arts in Language and Communication with IT is an in-depth program focusing on the interplay between language, linguistics, and communication, integrated with Information Technology. This program is structured to develop students' academic and professional competencies in various aspects of language and communication, preparing them for diverse fields like academia, non-governmental organizations, and international entities.

Year 1: The first year lays the foundation with courses in language, linguistics, communication skills, history of communication, psychology of communication, verbal and non-verbal communication, and IT basics.

Year 3: The third year deepens the understanding with courses on English in bi-multilingual contexts, English phonology, semantics and pragmatics, crisis communication, spatial linguistics, and psycholinguistics, complemented by management of IT projects and multimedia systems.

Year 4: The final year culminates with advanced courses in sociolinguistics, practical English stylistics, discourse analysis, health communication, translation, creative writing, forensic linguistics, and organizational communication, alongside advanced IT topics like human-computer interaction and information assurance.

This program aims to produce graduates with a comprehensive understanding of language and communication, enhanced by IT skills, making them versatile for various professional settings. The integration of IT skills ensures that graduates are well-prepared for the digital demands of modern communication fields.
"The program integrates advanced IT skills with linguistic and communicative studies, enabling students to effectively apply technology in analyzing and addressing language-related issues in diverse professional settings."
"Students engage in practical projects and internships that foster a deeper understanding of digital communication platforms and tools, enhancing their capabilities in media, corporate communication, and digital content creation."

fields.course_name: Bachelor of Arts (Literature, With IT)
fields.course_objectives:
On the successful completion of this course the learner should be able to:

Demonstrate knowledge of literary art and the theoretical postulates that have evolved within the art.
Relate developments in literature to the dynamics of historical and social change.
Correctly interpret literary texts and effectively present literary analysis.
Demonstrate an appreciation of the literatures of different geographical regions.
Undertake independent literary research.
Cultivate a deeper understanding of the diverse cultural contexts and perspectives that shape literary works, enhancing the ability to engage with texts from a global viewpoint.

Develop skills in critical thinking and literary criticism, enabling students to analyze and critique literary works with a nuanced understanding of various literary theories and methodologies.

Encourage creativity and originality in the interpretation of literary texts, fostering a unique and personal engagement with literature.

Provide a foundation for careers in education, publishing, and writing, where a deep understanding of literature can be applied in a range of professional contexts.

Promote lifelong learning and a love for literature, inspiring students to continue exploring the vast and varied landscape of literary works beyond their academic studies.
Equip students with the ability to communicate effectively about literature, both in writing and orally, preparing them for roles that require articulation and discussion of complex ideas and themes.

Foster an understanding of the role of literature in shaping societal values and personal identities, encouraging students to reflect on the power of narrative in both historical and contemporary contexts.
fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The Bachelor of Arts programme in the Department of Literature of the University of Nairobi helps students to respond sensitively to a wealth pool of literature that uses oral and written modes of transmission, exists in poetic, dramatic and prose genres and traverses regional and national cultures. In the process, students acquire tools to evaluate literature, discover the


language literature uses, learn skills for staging and performing drama, and learn creative writing.

This syllabus takes into consideration the recent local and global developments in literature as well as recent trends in the marketability of Literature graduates.  Kenya is no longer a literary desert and a lot of literary works, written in the full range of literary genres have becomes available in the last decade and a half.  Therefore, in addition to oral literature, Kenyan written literature deserves a place of its own and a more vigorous study.  As such, this syllabus gives it a more prominent place, separating it from East African Literature as had been the case.  Furthermore, east Africa has become a larger community and the content of east African literature has been expanded to include literary works from Southern Sudan, Burundi, Rwanda and Somalia.  In order to cover the full range of the African Continent, attention has been given to the literature of North-Africa.

 

On the global scene, Kenya is expanding her contacts with the countries of the Far East, therefore, in addition to Indian and Japanese, we are now also proposing courses in Chinese and Korean Literature.

 

We believe that the new courses offered will give an advantage to those who opt to teach, become journalists or literary critics and professionals in Kenya, at international schools, the African region and the Middle East of the rest of the world.  In addition, the undergraduate students will be exposed to a wide variety of Literatures which will give them a strong foundation in preparation of the revised MA in Literature course, offering specializations in African Literature, Literature of the Global South, and European Literature.



 

The aim of this syllabus is to create a strong theoretical, philosophical and practical foundation in the study and appreciation of Literature.  The syllabus focuses on the theoretical, historical, regional, global and generic components of the discipline so as to produce graduates who can confidently and completely handle literary texts from varied socio-cultural environments, but without neglecting the centrality of African and the Diaspora.  Introductory Literature courses are meant to equip the students with basic analytical and theoretical skills as well as aesthetic appreciation of literature are offered in the first and second years.  More complex textual appreciation is handled in the subsequent two years.  More complex textual appreciation is handled in the subsequent two years.  The rest of the syllabus caters for a broader exposure to literary texts through prose, poetry, drama as well as oral literature within the framework of textual and generic variety.  This programme caters for both Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Education students.  The programme takes into consideration the specific needs of B.Ed students as teachers in secondary school.

all facets of human activity and therefore deserves a central place in our curriculum. The program introduces students to
the theoretical issues in music, the different types of music and their evolution, as well as equipping them with skills
to compose and analyse Develop the skills to read and write different genres of music.
Foster a comprehensive understanding of music history and criticism, enabling students to become informed and articulate advocates for the arts in contemporary society.
Foster a deep understanding of music theory and history, exploring the cultural and social impact of music across different eras and regions.
Develop practical skills in music composition, performance, and production, encouraging creativity and artistic expression.

fields.course_general_info_and_about:
The Bachelor of Arts in Music with IT is a comprehensive program that combines the richness of music, dance, and theater with the nuances of Information Technology. It offers a wide spectrum of performing art specializations, equipping students with the knowledge and skills necessary to excel in the creative economy. The program's structure is carefully designed to cover various aspects of performing arts, from theoretical foundations to practical applications in a global context.

Program Structure:

Year 1: Introduces the basics of music, theater, dance, performing arts, and IT. Students learn about music and theater appreciation, dance and movement, music in drama, and the development of music and drama, coupled with foundational IT skills.

Year 2: Delves deeper into music theory and musicianship, exploring the philosophy of dance, performing arts therapy, arts in education, and indigenous music and drama in East Africa, alongside advanced IT skills.

Year 3: Offers specialization in music or theater studies. Music students study advanced music theory, composition, music history, and notation. Theatre students focus on scripting, directing, acting, dance techniques, and practical performance. Both specializations include research methods and IT project management.

Year 4: Music students continue with composition, orchestration, conducting, ethnomusicology, music production, and advanced practical performance. Theatre students explore African and Western drama, theater management, dance techniques, and editing for electronic media. Both streams cover advanced IT topics like human-computer interaction and information security.

This program is designed to prepare students for diverse roles in the creative and performing arts industry, integrating arts and technology in a way that reflects the evolving dynamics of the global job market. Graduates will have the skills to engage in the developmental aspects of community work and contribute innovatively to various sectors of the creative economy.
